docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Low-cadence, high-force aerobic work to build torque control, postural stability, and durable climbing strength without excessive recovery cost.

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text: Late Base to establish torque mechanics; Early Build to consolidate; Race Prep to maintain neuromuscular specificity for climbing.

docs.title: Variants Overview
docs.text:
• Seated Torque: stability & glute drive at 50–60 rpm.
  • Standing Torque: whole-chain tension & balance at 45–55 rpm.

docs.title: Variant Usage Logic
docs.text: Seated for baseline control and tissue load tolerance; standing for specific climbing stability and posture.

docs.title: Progression Rules
docs.text: Week-to-week: extend time-in-tension, not force; prioritize technique quality and cadence retention.

docs.title: Session Design
docs.text: Structure archetypes only (e.g., discrete torque blocks within an aerobic ride; terrain = gentle climbs or erg). Maintain smooth force; quiet upper body.

docs.title: Intensity Protocol
docs.text: RPE 4–6/10 aerobic; %HRmax ~70–85%; monitor HR drift and posture. Stay below threshold; torque is the stressor.

docs.title: Fueling Protocol
docs.text: CHO 40–60 g/hr (Z2 torque), hydrate 500–800 ml/hr, sodium 500–900 mg/hr. Recovery: CHO+protein within 60 min. Female-specific: avoid low energy availability.

docs.title: Safeguards
docs.text: Strict technique; gradual load; stop on knee/hip pain; prefer warm conditions for tissue readiness.

docs.title: Adaptations & Testing
docs.text: ↑ strength endurance, ↑ torque control, ↑ climbing stability. Field anchors: cadence retention, HR drift, stable RPE.

docs.title: Integration & Substitution
docs.text: Pairs with Z2 LSD and Sweet Spot blocks. Sub with Z2 Hills if mechanics degrade.

docs.title: Block Integration — Signal to Fire
docs.text: Where it fits: Late Base (primary), Early Build (support), Race Prep (maintenance). Frequency: 1×/week typical; reduce in VO₂-focused weeks. Testing / Feedback: Stable cadence & posture at target torque; HR drift <5%.

docs.title: Science Behind
docs.text: Strength endurance at low cadence increases force per stroke within aerobic constraints; supports motor unit recruitment and connective tissue tolerance.

docs.title: Real-World Best Practice
docs.text: High-performance programs integrate torque 1×/wk in Base→Build, often on controlled terrain or erg. Emphasis on form first; load second.
